com.jjoe64.graphview.helper

Class StaticLabelsFormatter

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.jjoe64.graphview.helper.StaticLabelsFormatter
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    LabelFormatter

    public class StaticLabelsFormatter
extends java.lang.Object
implements LabelFormatter
    Use this label formatter to show static labels. Static labels are not bound to the data. It is typical used for show text like "low", "middle", "high". You can set the static labels for vertical or horizontal individually and you can define a label formatter that is to be used if you don't define static labels. For example if you only use static labels for horizontal labels, graphview will use the dynamicLabelFormatter for the vertical labels.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      protected LabelFormatter mDynamicLabelFormatter
      the label formatter that will format the labels for that there are no static labels defined.
      protected GraphView mGraphView
      reference to the graphview
      protected java.lang.String[] mHorizontalLabels
      the horizontal labels, ordered form the left to the right if it is null, the labels will be generated via the #dynamicLabelFormatter
      protected java.lang.String[] mVerticalLabels
      the vertical labels, ordered from bottom to the top if it is null, the labels will be generated via the #dynamicLabelFormatter
      protected Viewport mViewport
      reference to the viewport

        public void setDynamicLabelFormatter(LabelFormatter dynamicLabelFormatter)

      • setViewport

        public void setViewport(Viewport viewport)
        Description copied from interface: LabelFormatter
        will be called in order to have a reference to the current viewport. This is useful if you need the bounds to generate your labels. You store this viewport in as member variable and access it e.g. in the LabelFormatter.formatLabel(double, boolean) method.
        Specified by:
        setViewport in interface LabelFormatter
        Parameters:
        viewport - the used viewport
